loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.es: El señor Reynaldo habita en el barrio Hialia IV, barrio que se ubica en la capital Managua, tiene 29 años de edad, se encuentra casado, donde su esposa es comerciante y le apoya con los gastos de la casa, juntos tienen dos hijos uno de 11 y 8 años de edad, ambos están estudiando y le ayudan a sus padres en el negocio. Actualmente el señor Reynaldo se dedica a la administración de su pequeño negocio, donde vende granos básicos, tortillas, frijoles, negocio que lo inicio hace mas de un año, para el poder iniciar esta actividad tuvo que vender una finca, donde pudo comprar una pequeña casa en la capital y luego logro establecer su negocio en su casa, el anhela ver mas grande este negocio y así mismo poder mejorar las instalaciones de su casa; por tanto el trabaja con  créditos que AFODENIC le ha facilitado, para invertir en la comprar de mercadería y poder incrementar sus ventas, por tal motivo actualmente esta solicitando C$ 12,000.00 aun plazo de 12 meses, para adquirir mas capital de trabajo, sobre todo en estos últimos meses que la demanda es buena.
texts.en:
Reynaldo lives in the Hialia IV neighborhood located in Managua. He is 29 years old and married to a sales woman who helps with the household bills. They have two children together of ages 11 and 8, both who are in school and help their father with his business. Currently, Reynaldo makes a living by running his small business that sells whole grains, tortillas, and beans. He started this business more than a year ago with the proceeds from the sale of his farm enabling him to buy a small house in the capital and establish his business. He strives to see his business grow so that he can afford home improvements. Consequently, he works with the loans that AFODENIC has given him by investing in the purchase of merchandise that will increase his sales. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of 12,0000 C for a period of 12 months in order to acquire more capital for his work, especially in these last months when the demand for his products is high.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase basic grains

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en: Mrs. Pheap K. is 33 years old and lives in Pour village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a tailor. Aside from this business, she is a pig breeder. Because her pig breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy more piglets, pig food, and medicine for her pig breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living after she sells her pigs. Her husband, Mr. Chi Mengly, is a farmer.  Mrs. Pheap K. has two children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, pig food, and medicine for her pig breeding business.

loans.name: Lilia Esther

texts.es:
La señora Lilia Esther, socia del Banco Comunal “El Alto Mayo”, vive en el Departamento de San Martín, provincia y distrito de Rioja, se dedica a  la  venta de ropa para damas, caballeros y niños, zapatillas y artículos de regalos. Su negocio está ubicado en su propia casa, lugar donde llegan sus clientes.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,700, el cual será cancelado en 06 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de ropa para damas, caballeros y niños como polos, blusas, camisas, pantalones y juguetes para aprovechar las fiestas de navidad y  poder satisfacer así los requerimientos de sus clientes.

Tiene 41 años de edad, es madre de 05 hijos, 2 de ellos todavía están a su cargo y quienes son su motor para seguir trabajando. Su meta es mantener bien surtido su negocio.
texts.en:
Lilia Esther, member of the Alto Mayo Communal Bank, lives in the San Martin Region, in the province and district of Rioja. She sells clothing for women, men, and children, as well as sneakers and gift items. Her business is located in her own home, where her customers visit. With this loan of $575, which will be paid back in six months, she will purchase women's, men's, and children's clothes such as polo shirts, blouses, button-up shirts, and pants, as well as toys to have on hand for the Christmas holiday and to be able to satisfy her customers' demands. She is 41 years old and the mother of five, two of whom are still in her care and who are her inspiration to continue working. Her goal is to keep her business well stocked.

Translated from Spanish by Olivia Engkvist, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase women's, men's, and children's clothes such as polo shirts, blouses, button-up shirts, pants, as well as toys

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa tiene 52 años, es madre de cinco hijos, todos ellos independientes y de familia pero viven con ella en su casa propia. Se dedica a la venta de comida desde hace 5 años. Se levanta muy temprano, a las 3:00am  para preparar los diversos platos que vende a los trabajadores de una constructora, lo más demandado es el tradicional caldo de gallina, que es una sopa muy consistente y que generalmente se toma para recuperar fuerzas, a muy tardar Rosa acaba de vender su caldo a las 6:00 am, lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que sus clientes se sientan satisfechos de su buena atención y su buena sazón.  Además le es rentable porque no tiene competencia en la zona. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, y con el dinero que solicita va a mandar a construir un kiosco para vender con mayor comodidad, porque hasta el momento lo hace al aire libre.
texts.en:
Rosa is 52 and the mother of five children. They are all independent and have their own families, but they still live with Rosa in the house she owns. For five years she has earned her living by selling meals. She gets up very early, at 3:00AM, to prepare a variety of meals, which she sells to the workers on a construction site. In highest demand is her traditional chicken soup, which is very hearty, and typically eaten to get one's strength back. Rosa is done selling her soup by 6:00AM at the latest. What she likes about her work is that her clients take pleasure in her good service and flavorful food. In addition, business is profitable as there is no competition in the area. This will be Rosa's first loan with MFP. She plans to use the money to have a kiosk built so she can be more comfortable; until now she has been out in the open.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a kiosk for her business

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
Saturnina R. owns a fish pond. She raises fish (tilapia) and sells all of them to restaurant owners to serve for their dishes. She also sells to middlemen who retail her fish in the market. Tilapia is a fresh water fish which earns popularity in the Philippines.

Saturnina is 48 years old and has three children. She worked before in the municipal building in her town as a casual employee. She was not happy about her previous job and decided to have a business. She started her business in 2008, the same year CEVI started its operations. Her profits from her fish pond business help her send her children to school.

Saturnina is requesting a loan of 6,000 pesos from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy feed for the fish. She believes that her loan will bring her more fish to sell. When that happens, she will no longer worry where to get the money to spend for their needs.

CEVI is an organization that helps its members start and expand their businesses. CEVI provides its clients not just with credit but also with training for their business and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase feed for the fish in her pond.

loans.name: Orabbiddin

texts.en: Orabbiddin M. is a young businessman who has been raising and selling cattle for 5 years. He brings livestock from Kyrgyzstan to sell in Tajikistan. To supplement his income, he also buys vegetables from collective farmers to trade at the local bazaar. Orabbiddin would like to use this Kiva loan to build a summer barn for his cows. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: summer cow barn building

loans.name: Ailua

texts.en: Ailua N. I., 48, is married with three children.  She has two years of experience in the Pancake business. She sells to the village people and the public six days per week. She has no previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~100 USD).  SPBD loans are Ailua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Ailua's loan will be used buy things needed for her business such as sacks of flour, sugar, cooking oil and a large frying pan.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for her pancake business.

loans.name: David

texts.es: David acaba de cumplir 40 años de edad, es casado hace 12 años y tiene 5 hijos. Desde niño aprendió los cuidados de cada uno de sus cultivos; como la papa, habas, cebada y alverjas. Desde que hizo familia, empezó también a criar ganado, que su esposa es la encargada de pastar. En estos últimos años está sembrando mayormente alverjas, por ser muy rentables y de poca inversión. A cada una de sus chacras las cuida delicadamente, con su mirada serena puesta en cada una de sus siembras observando su proceso. En todo este tiempo sus cultivos le brindaron el bienestar económico para el sostenimiento de su familia y la educación de sus hijos, por eso David ama su trabajo y se siente muy orgulloso de labrar la tierra con sus propias manos. Y ahora que sus hijos han crecido, lo apoyan con sus cultivos, en consecuencia, tienen planes de  incrementar su producción y no sólo tener tierras de regadío, sino también tierras temporales. David es un cliente muy sereno y centrado en cada uno de las reuniones de pago con los demás integrantes de su banco comunal, este es su 7mo préstamo con MFP, donde todo este tiempo demostró puntualidad y responsabilidad. El dinero que viene solicitando es para la compra de fertilizantes químicos, para el crecimiento de las alverjas, con la finalidad de apurar el proceso desarrollo de la planta.
texts.en:
David has just turned 40 years old, he has been married for 12 years and has 5 children. Since he was a boy he learned how to care for each of his crops such as potatoes, beans, barley and peas. When he began his family, he also began to raise livestock, which his wife is responsible for. In recent years he has been planting more peas because they are very profitable with little investment. At each of his small farms he delicately cares for them, his serene watch fixed on each of his plants watching their process.

Through all of this time his cultivations have given him financial well being for the support of his family and the education of his children. For this reason David loves his job and feels very proud to work the land with his own hands. And now that his children have grown, they help him with his cultivations and in consequence they have plans to increase their production and to not only have irrigated land but also temporary land.

David is a very serene client and is stable in his attendance at each repayment meeting of his communal bank along with the rest of the members. This is his seventh loan with MFP, where all of this time he has demonstrated punctuality and responsibility. The money that he solicits is for the purchase of chemical fertilizers for the cultivation of peas, with the purpose of speeding along the growth of the plants.

Translated from Spanish by Breanne Kochert, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of fertilizers

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa D. is fifty-four years old. She is married and has eight children, three daughters and five sons. She says almost all her children are out of school. The last two are currently in senior high school.

Yaa lives with her husband and some of her children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She is a trader. She trades in all kinds of footwear and printed textiles. Yaa procures the footwear and the printed textiles from Accra and sells in her community by hawking. She says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Yaa has been in business for seven years and desires to expand her business. She is hopeful of improving upon her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy footwear and textiles for resale

loans.name: Rubina Munawar Hussain Group

texts.en:
Rubina baji is married to M. H. and is the group leader of four other women. She has been living in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan, for the past 10 years. Her husband is a musician and runs a musical group of 10 people. They sing songs on occasions such as weddings and birthdays when people call them for providing entertainment. Rubina baji is engaged in the cot-knitting business. She knits cots on orders and earns income. She does this work to share the financial burden of her husband. She is applying for a loan to buy a musical instrument (guitar) for her husband’s musical group.

Parveen baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy iron for making iron rods to sell. Nazia parveen baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Razia baji wants a loan to buy goats for her animal-selling business.

This is a group loan and the loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a musical instrument for musical group

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: Carlos es padre soltero, tiene 33 años, vive con su hija de 3 añitos, su madre y su hermana. Desde hace 8 años se dedica al transporte de pasajeros (taxi) en su motocarro, y para incrementar sus ingresos económicos, desde hace 2 años empezó a criar pollos en un galpón que construyó el mismo en un espacio de su casa, los cuales, después de que llegan a un tamaño y peso adecuado (cada 45 días), los vende. Ambas labores le ayudan a satisfacer las necesidades de su hogar, por lo que está muy satisfecho por lo que hasta el momento ha conseguido. Para un futuro cercano, Carlos quiere empezar a criar pavos y cerdos, pues ha notado que la carne de estos animales, también es muy demandada. Este es su 5to crédito con MFP, y lo que le gusta de su banco comunal es que existe compañerismo y solidaridad entre todos sus compañeros y compañeras. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará pollos bebé y suficiente alimento para su crianza.
texts.en:
Carlos is a single father, he is 33 years old, and he lives with his baby daughter of 3 years, with his wife and sister. For the past 8 years he has been providing public transport (taxi services) on his motorcycle. And to supplement his income, 2 years ago he started raising chickens in a coop he built in a space on his property. When the chickens grow to a certain size and weight (about every 45 days) he sells them. Both jobs help him fill the household necessities. He is so happy to have achieved what he has to date. For the near future, Carlos would like to start raising turkeys and pigs. He has noted that the meat products from this animals is in great demand. This is his 5th credit with MFP (Kiva Field Partner). What he loves best about his community bank is that there exists a sense of friendship and solidarity among the members. With the funds he is requesting he will pruchase chicks and enough feed to raise them.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase chicks and feed.

loans.name: Frene Yasmina

texts.es:
Yasmina es socia del Banco Comunal El Trébol.
Yasmina es soltera, tiene 19 años y vive con sus padres, Yasmina vende ropa a pedido, que ofrece a amigos y familiares, sus ventas son al crédito. Además Yasmina ayuda a su mama en la atención de su restaurante.
Yasmina necesita un préstamo de 900 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de polos, pantalones.
Los sueños de Yasmina son tener un negocio grande y ser empresaria.
texts.en:
Yasmina is a member of the El Trébol Communal Bank. Yasmina is single 19-year-old and lives with her parents. Yasmina sells clothes upon request, which she offers to friends and family. Her sales are on credit. In addition, Yasmina helps her mom take care of her restaurant. Yasmina needs a loan of 900 soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of polos and pants. Yasmina's dream is to become the owner of her own big business.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of polos and pants.

loans.name: Aydee

texts.es: Aydee tiene 43 años, vive con su esposo y el menor de sus hijos de 14 años en su casa propia. Desde hace 22 años se dedica a la agricultura y a la ganadería, siembra principalmente papa y junto a su esposo comparte las tareas diarias que implica esta actividad y los fines de semana cuando hay cosecha los apoyan sus hijos mayores que vienen de otra ciudad. Todos estos largos años de experiencia le han servido para afrontar situaciones difíciles que ahora ve con gran logro. Aydee tiene clientes que siempre compran directamente en su casa o en sus tierras de cultivo mientras están realizando las tareas de la cosecha. Sus planes a futuro son de seguir dedicándose a la agricultura y a la ganadería hasta donde puedan con sus fuerzas porque es de gran satisfacción para ellos permanecer en su tierra natal. Esta es la 12ava oportunidad en que Aydee tiene un préstamo con MFP, ella es una de las integrantes más antiguas de su banco comunal y considera que esta experiencia ha sido muy buena porque aprendió el valor del ahorro y de la amistad. El dinero que viene solicitando será invertido en la compra de un toro para su actividad como ganadera hasta que espera su próxima cosecha.
texts.en:
Aydee is 43 years old, and lives in a house she owns with her husband and the youngest of her children who is 14 years old. For 22 years, she has dedicated herself to farming and raising livestock. She plants mostly potatoes and shares the daily tasks of this endeavor with her husband. When there is a harvest on a weekend, she is also helped by her older children who travel from another city. All the long years of experience have taught her how to manage difficult situations that she now can handle well. Aydee has customers that always buy from her directly at her home, or on her farmlands while she works her crops. Her future plans include continuing to dedicate herself to farming and raising livestock, as it is a great satisfaction for her to be able to remain on the land of her birth. This is the 12th opportunity for Aydee to receive a loan with MFP. She is one of the oldest members of her cooperative bank, and she considers her involvement in this group to have been a great experience because she learned the value of saving and of friendship. The funds she is requesting will be invested into the purchase of a bull to add to her livestock activities, while she waits for her next harvest.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of a bull.

loans.name: Melrose

texts.en:
Melrose S. is from the village of Poblacion 4, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 34 years old. Melrose is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Melrose owns and operates a business venture raising fish. The main source of income for the business comes from raising fish for sale. Melrose has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Melrose joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melrose is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Melrose from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Serif

texts.en: Serif is 31 years old and married with a child who is in school. He sells motor spare parts. He is requesting the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more spare parts to sell so that he can meet the demand of his increasing number of customers and make more profit.  He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase motor spare parts to sell

loans.name: Suzan's Group

texts.en:
Suzan N. is the leader of this lending group, based in Lugazi. She is thirty years old and married with four children. In total she cares for ten dependents. Suzan has been selling new clothes in Kiyindi market for ten years and, although her business is seasonal with stiff competition, she is able to continue due to her unique products and good customer care.

Suzan has a dream of owning a shop rather than working in the market, so as to be best placed to look after her family. She also hopes to educate her family and build her own house to rent out. Suzan needs a loan to be able to pay her children’s school fees and buy more stock for her business.

loans.use: Buy clothes stocks and pay children's school fees

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita P. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 37 years old. Amelita is married and has 6 older children. To make a living, Amelita owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling different goods in the local community. Amelita has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Amelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amelita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Amelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Imoi

texts.en: Imoi S. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase more brewing materials. Imoi is 40 years old and is married to a security guard. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bigger bar for selling beer, wines, etc. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more brewing materials

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is a new member of a KIVA field partner in the Philippines, ASHI. Through ASHI she requested a loan to start up a business that will change her family’s way of living. Through the profits she will be making, she hopes to send three out of four of her children to school until their graduation from college. Presently the range of her children’s age is from 10 to 21 years old.

Although Elizabeth felt quite disappointed with her eldest child who didn't finish her schooling after high school, she has not stopped dreaming for the rest of her children. Her disappointment has led her to work harder for to increase her family’s income. The food market business she plans to put up will be her means to augment her husband’s sporadic income as a farm laborer.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of sugar which she will market in their village

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza G. is from the village of Pangabuan Tangub City. She is 45 years old. Riza is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Riza owns and operates a "sari-sari" (variety) store, selling different products for daily use and dry goods in the local community. Riza has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $71 a month from these activities.

In 2008, Riza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Riza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Riza is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her child's tuition fees and for daily needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en: Rosalie D. is from the village of Colupan, Bajo, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Rosalie owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 1,600 PHP a month. In 2008, Rosalie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to pay for services to increase crop yield. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk

loans.name: Kamoliddin

texts.en:
Kamoliddin is married with two children. His family lives in Tursunzade, Tajikistan. Kamoliddin has a grocery sales business. His business boasts fresh groceries, reasonable prices, flexible and quality client service, and uniqueness and variety of merchandise. Kamoliddin works hard to develop his business and make his business profitable. He is requesting a loan of $2000 USD to reconstruct and modernize his vending pavilion, increase turnover capital and purchase an assortment of goods for retail sale. Kamoliddin has personal goals too. He is planning to use the generated profits to buy a new vehicle and remodel his private house. Kamoliddin is a conscientious and focused manager of his resources and always plans his time and finances. In all his business dealings, he is guided by a sense of trust and goodwill towards others. We believe these qualities will help him repay his loan without any delinquencies. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs for increasing the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: San Francisco De Totos Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal San Francisco D. Totos, se encuentra ubicado en la comunidad D. Totos, distrito del mismo nombre, provincia D. Cangallo, departamento D. Ayacucho. Esta comunidad se ubica a 3,500 msnm y a 154 Km D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho, se dedica principalmente a la ganadería y la agricultura.

Margarita, es casada y tiene 05 hijos. Margarita se dedica a al venta D. animales menores, las cuales compra en caseríos y ferias, los cuales venD. en su comunidad, negocio en el cual es ayudada por sus hijos. Margarita requiere D. un préstamo, el cual invertirá en su negocio adquiriendo más animales. Ella trabaja arduo, ya quiere que sus hijos lleguen a ser profesionales.

Hilda es casada y tiene 03 hijos. Hilda tiene por negocio una bodega, donD. venD. productos D. primera necesidad, los cuales compra en la ciudad D. Ayacucho y venD. en su comunidad.
Hilda, requiere D. un préstamo, con el cual abastecerá su negocio. Hilda, quiere mejorar su calidad D. vida, y tener una casa propia, para lo cual ya se encuentra ahorrando.
texts.en:
The San Francisco D. Totos Communal Bank is located in the Totos community, in the district by the same name, province of Cangallo, department of Ayacucho. This community is located 3,500 meters above sea level, some 154 km from the city of Ayacucho. This community is involved chiefly in cattle farming and agriculture.

Margarita is a married mother with 5 children. She sells small animals, which she buys at farmhouses and fairs. She then sells them in her community, and her children help her out with the business. Margarita needs a loan, which she will invest in purchasing more animals. She works arduously because she wants her children to become professionals.

Hilda is a married mother with 3 children. She owns a general store in which she sells basic need items, which she purchases in Ayacucho and sells in her community.

Hilda needs a loan with which she will restock her business. Hilda would like to improve her quality of life and have her own home, for which she is now saving money.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in their small businesses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Shadi

texts.en: Shadi is a very ambitious farmer who started raising chickens in 2004. He is a 27-year-old single man who wants to prosper with his project to make enough money to get married and have a big family. He lives in Beit lahia in Gaza, where they compete in raising cattle, chicken and farming. So he wants $3,000 to improve his work by buying advanced equipment for chicken raising and by purchasing air conditioning that will help increase his chickens' health and eventually increase his sales. Shadi appreciates your help and promises to make use of it in the best way to prosper in his work.

loans.use: To buy advanced equipment

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn B. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old. Evelyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Evelyn is just starting this business. (Evelyn's first business was managing a clothing store. She opted to have a sari-sari store during her 2nd loan.)

In 2009, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mila's Group

texts.en:
Mila L. is from the village of Mabini. She is 47 years old. Mila is the group leader of a five member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Mila L.'s Group.

Mila is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Mila owns a general store which sells a variety of different products in the local community. Mila has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Mila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mila is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Mila from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offerings

loans.name: Rhenee

texts.en: Rhenee P. believes that poverty is not a hindrance to one’s success. Being a member of ASHI, Kiva's field partner in the Philippines, she feels privileged for having such great help. Through the financial assistance offered by the institution, she has been able to start an inland fish culture and has the ability to support her rice farming business. Proceeds from these businesses have been the source for Rhenee’s family to obtain their basic needs and improve their quality of life; at this point, their only 13-year-old child is not yet incurring a large amount of money for his education. However, Rhenee still wants to save some of her profit to be able to send her child to a high standard school for good quality education in college. With her husband partnering her in the business, Rhenee is requesting a larger loan to purchase materials for manufacturing a “balsa” (raft) to be used for fishing and to increase the volume of fish they farm. In so doing, they will be able to supply their customers' increasing demands and increase their profit.

loans.use: To purchase materials for making a raft for fishing

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes D. is from the village of Olango. She is 31 years old, married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lourdes plants and harvests rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately $790 whenever she harvest her rice plants (palay).

In 2008, Lourdes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 26,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers. This will be her 5th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Hannan

texts.en:
Hannan J. sells beer at her bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Hannan is 31 years-old and is married with a husband that is a builder. She has three children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her bar.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Angele

texts.en:
Madame Angele T. is 44 years old. She was born in Lomé and now lives in Adidogomé, Togo. She is married with three children and her husband is retired.

Angele has been selling cereals since 1998. She requests 300,000 CFA to purchase more maize, sorghum, and wood. This is her second loan with WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase more maize, sorghum, and wood

loans.name: Mrs. Orn Ung Village Bank Group

texts.en: Nine people in Manong Leu village in Prey Veng province are seeking a village bank loan. Mrs. Orn U. is the group leader, selected by the other members. Each member will use a portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Orn U. is a pig breeder at her home. Her husband, Mr. Rey Chei, is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice in order to support his family. Now she has a problem because the soil in her husband’s field is infertile. To improve production, Mrs. Orn U. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. She is the mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory. The others are attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Jobielyn

texts.en:
Jobielyn D. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 22 years old. Jobielyn is single. To make a living, Jobielyn owns and operates a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling electronic prepaid cellphone loads in the local community. She is also engaged in a dealership of Natasha products like shoes, sandals and personal care products. Jobielyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jobielyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jobielyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jobielyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jobielyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en:
Jerry G. is from the village of Southwestern Calamba, Misamis Occidental. He is 49 years old, married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Jerry owns a business venture in the transportation sector motorcycle for lease. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from the income generated in his business. Jerry has been engaged in his business for over 11 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. He is also a company driver which he earns a monthly income of 6,000.00.

In 2006, Jerry joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jerry has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. Jerry is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used for personal purposes. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Jerry from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For personal purposes

loans.name: Tweyombekye Women's Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
Her social and affable nature has been her winning calling card in the 20 years she has been operating her stationary business in Ntungamo town. Her experience in this business has taught her the virtue of being cordial to your clientele.

Given the nature of her business where competition is cutthroat, this has come in really handy for the 56-year-old B. Kellen, a mother of eight, who divulges she has been able to make commendable strides in the improvement of her family’s welfare. Ever since she began her business where she prints, types, binds and photocopies the client’s information alongside selling reams of paper, pens, files, clip boards and other things.

On a weekly basis, she says she makes 300,000 Ugandan shillings as profit. With this amount of money she has managed to educate all of her eight children. Her future plans are to elevate her financial status through the expansion of her business. With this loan she says she wants to buy a computer and also expand her operating area.

loans.use: Business expansion and buying a computer.

loans.name: Lita's Group

texts.en:
Lita S., from the village of Bayabay Panalsalan Plaridel Misamis Occidental, is the 19-year-old group leader of a three-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Bayabas.

Lita, a married mother of an infant, owns and operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 6000 PHP.

In 2009, Lita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 4000 PHP from GDMPC that was used to invest in expanding the business, she is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be Lita's second from GDMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: expand his business

loans.name: Juana Oilda

texts.es:
La Sra. Juana tiene 61 años. Esta casada con Eugenio Rojas, tienen tres hijos, dos mayores y uno menor de edad. Ella tiene su taller de confección en su domicilio desde el año 2005.
Ella necesita de este crédito para adquirir tela polar para la confección de prendas para damas y niños de temporada invierno. Ella ya tiene varios pedidos para confeccionar buzos para niños en edad escolar.
 En el futuro desea contar con un mayor numero de maquinas ya industriales para poder aumentar su producción y ampliar su pequeña empresa familiar.
texts.en:
Juana, age 60, is married to Eugenio Rojas. They have three children. Two of them are adults, and one is still a dependent. Her workshop has been in her home since 2005. She needs this loan to get polar fleece to make women’s and children’s winter clothes. She has various orders to make sweatshirts for school age children. In the future she wants to have more industrial machines in order to be able to increase her production and expand her small family business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric and accessories to make clothes

loans.name: Jolidenw Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées, les femmes du groupe Jolidenw, ont en moyenne 40 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-coungo, sous préfecture de Fana, région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce de produits cosmétique, de condiments, de fruits et de pâte d’arachide.                                                                                                             
Ces femmes du groupe Jolidenw sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire.                                                                                       
MATOUKOUNE K., compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des paquets de condiments alimentaires.
Elle s’approvisionne en condiments le plus généralement avec les grossistes de Bamako et au marché de Marka-coungo et effectue sa vente sur place et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Jolidenw group are all around 40 years old, married with three children, and live in large extended families in the village of Marka-Coungo, in the municipality of Fana, the Koulikoro region (the second largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through friends and family and sell cosmetics, condiments, fruit and peanut butter for a living. The women are on their fifth microfinance loan. Matoukoune K., a member of the group, aims to use her loan in order to buy packets of condiments. She generally sources her goods from wholesalers at the Bamako and Marka-Coungo markets, and sells her wares from home or at the markets for cash or credit sales to a customer base composed of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA, some of which will be used to meet her family's needs, and the rest will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing condiments

loans.name: Alejandro

texts.es:
El Sr, L. Sairitupac Alejandro es de estado civil soltero, no tiene carga familiar, vive con sus padres y hermanos con los cuales comparte los gastos. 
Trabaja como obrero en el campo y además tiene una mototaxi la cual alquila y así recibe otro ingreso. 
Solicita el préstamo para mantenimiento y arreglos de su mototaxi. Su meta es poder adquirir otra moto y asi poder tener mas adelante una casa propia.
texts.en:
Mr. L. Sairitupac Alejandro is single and he doesn't have children. He lives with his parents and with his siblings. They all share the household expenses. 

He works as a laborer in the fields and he also owns a rickshaw that he rents out as an additional source of income. 

He requests a loan to provide his rickshaw with maintenance repairs. His goal is to acquire another motorcycle rickshaw and to save enough money for a house of his own.

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma V. is from the town of Banga. She is 39 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Vilma owns & operates an agricutural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. One of Vilma's dreams in life is to have all her children finish college and for them to have bright futures. 

Vilma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase sacks of fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Tadjikan

texts.en:
Tadjikan I. is a widow with two grown children who lives in Nooken village, in the south of Kyrgyzstan.  In 1990, in order to support her family, she began her business in cattle breeding and cotton cultivating. Using the amount of 50,000 Kyrgyz Soms to purchase livestock and plant seeds, Tadjikan worked hard to make her business successful.  

Today, she has four milch cows and fourteen sheep and earns about 5,000 Kyrgyz Soms monthly. To reduce expenses for the livestock's foraging, she pastures her livestock in mountainous areas with native grasses. Currently, Tadjikan’s four grandchildren live with her, which further added to the family’s expenditures so she had to make strong efforts to earn their living. That’s why Tadjikan is applying for a loan of 100,000 Kyrgyz Soms to buy cattle, which will allow her to enlarge her business. 

In future, Tadjikan dreams of seeing her grandchildren educated and progressive people. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en: Alicia C., from the town of Surallah, is 48 years old, married, and has three children aged 15, 14 and 7, all attending school. To help sustain her children's education and meet their needs, she helps her husband maintain their rice farm and also runs a sari-sari store where she sells canned goods and other products.  Because Alicia needs additional farm inputs and products to sell, she is requesting a loan of Php 15000, hopeful that it will be a big help to their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Kalira Echkilbaeva's Group

texts.en:
Kalira E. is the leader of this group. She is 50 and married. Kalira is the resident of a small town, Karabalta, which is located near Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan. She has a daughter and a son. Her son works in Russia, and her daughter makes money by working as a seller in the supermarket.  Kalira’s husband is retired. In order to earn money to cover their family's expenses, Kalira takes order and sews Kyrgyz national blankets, cloth and dressmaking supplies. She started her activity seven years ago with an initial investment of 5,000 soms. In this way, she earns 5,000 soms per month. This profit made it possible for her to save money and repair the house. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase fabrics and materials needed for sewing. In the future, Kalira wants to expand her business and open a sewing workshop.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Patricia Elizabeth

texts.es: La señora Elizabeth es comerciante, tiene una tienda de barrio en una zona peri urbana de la ciudad,  ella tiene cuatro hijos, tres de su primer matrimonio y uno del actual.  Su esposo es transportista, trabaja de taxista en el área urbana ambos trabajan muy duro para la manutención de su hogar, recientemente construyeron en su lote y es donde habitan antes Vivian en alquiler aunque es alejada la zona ellos están muy felices por que ya es su casa y tienen mayor libertad y comodidad. El Sr. Víctor lleva  a su esposa todos los días al mercado para abastecerse de insumos para la tienda como ser, carne, pan y otros insumos que tienen rotación diaria, ellos salen a las seis de la mañana y doña Elizabeth tiene que retornar a su domicilio sola con los bultos caminando por que el micro que la traslada la deja a siete cuadras de su domicilio, con el dinero del crédito comprara calaminas para la construcción de un tinglado para su tiendita, esta muy agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Sra. Elizabeth is a merchant who has a neighborhood store in a periurban section of the city. She has four children, three from her first marriage and one from her current one. Her husband works in transportation, driving a taxi in the urban areas. They both work hard to support their household and recently constructed on their lot. Previously they had rented in a distant area but are now very happy to have their house as well as greater freedom and comfort.

Sr. Victor brings his wife to the market every day so that she can stock up on supplies for her store such as meat, bread, and other items that sell on a daily basis. They leave at 6am and Doña Elizabeth returns home alone by walking with her packages since the market is seven blocks from her house. The money from this loan will be used to buy roofing sheets to build a shed for her little store.

She is very grateful to Emprender for the support it has provided.

loans.use: Purchase materials to build a storage shed for her store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more building materials for sale

loans.name: Zandra

texts.en:
Zandra S. is from the village of Kimanait, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 26 years-old and married with one school-aged child. To make a living, Zandra owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, detergents, junk food and toothpaste in the local community. Zandra has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Zandra joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. Zandra is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and junk food. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Zandra from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Madinah

texts.en:
Madinah K. is 43 years old and lives in the town of Gaba in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is single and has six children, all of whom are currently in school. Madinah has a poultry farm business, which she has run for two years.
To help expand her business, Madinah has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chickens for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Madinah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens for resale

loans.name: Dima

texts.en:
Dima is a 34-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  fishing and food vending.  She lives in the municipality of Medellin, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,000. Dima is borrowing PHP 10,000 to continue to fund the operations of her business. This will be her sixth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 5,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Dima aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To fund the operation of her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more plastics bowls and other utensils.

loans.name: Almaz

texts.en: Almaz M. is married with two children. She is an entrepreneur from the small village of Imishli. Almaz runs a business selling cometics and other household items in the central marketplace. Her enterprise is well-known for the flexible discount system she offers to her customers. Almaz has always wanted to be self-employed and decided 6 years ago to start her own business. Almaz wants to keep her enterprise running in order to provide for her family and support her elderly parents. She is requesting a loan of 1,000 AZN and promises to repay the loan without any lapses.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Franie

texts.en:
Franie Mamasig, S.. is from the village of Sinamar in the Philippines. He is 42 years old. Franie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Franie owns and operates an agricultural business, raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Franie has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Franie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Franie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Franie is now requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Franie from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children's tuition fees.
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase his crop yield

loans.name: Dias Francisco

texts.pt:
Dias Francisco B. nasceu no Distrito de Guija,  Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique casado pai de 5 filhos de idades entre 5 a 18 anos de idade, destes 4 vaõ a Escola. Fez somente 7ª classe não continuou devido a dificuldades financeiras pelos pais. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e naõ sustenta mais ninguem.

Saiu de Guija para Maputo a procura de melhores condições de vida, possui um negocio proprio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade ha mais de 7 anos. Naõ tem empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 4.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e a vezes consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimo em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigo que é cliente desta instituição.Este é o seu terceiro empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar mercadoria (óleo, Feijão, caldos, cebola  e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. Os emprestimos anteriores foram de 15.000.00mt ambos e foram para o comercio.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro. Pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para concluir a construção de dependencias e da sua loja.
texts.en:
Dias Francisco Biza was born in Guija District, Gaza Province in southern Mozambique. He is married and has five children aged 5 to 18; four of them go to school. Dias only finished seventh grade and did not continue with school because his parents had financial difficulties. He lives in his own house with his family and has no other dependents.

He left Guija to move to Maputo looking for better living conditions. For more than seven years he has had his own business selling staple goods. He has no employees and earns an income of about 4,000 meticais per month which he uses for household expenses. Sometimes he manages to save some money in his bank account.

Dias has never had loans from other banks. He learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is a customer of this institution. This is his third Hluvuku loan, and he is asking for 15,000 meticais, which he will use to buy merchandise (oil, beans, broth, onions and other items) to increase his inventory. The previous loans were both for 15,000 meticais, and both were for the business.

He promises to make his payments on time so he can take out more loans in the future. He intends to ask for other loans in order to finish building some rooms and his shop.

loans.use: to buy merchandise (oil, beans, broth, onions and other items)

loans.name: Kotognontala Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kotognontala, composé de femmes mariées et de veuve, ont en moyenne 29 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Nalla, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de poissons, de condiments et de tubercules.                                                                                                                                 
Les femmes du groupe Kotognontala sont à leur premier prêt et la SITAN C. qui est du groupe compte acheter des poissons avec les revendeurs de Fana pour les revendre quotidiennement au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10000 F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
Kotognontala is a group composed of married women and a widow. The group members average 29 years of age and three children each all living in traditional extended families in the village of Nalla, sub-prefecture of Fana, Region of Koulikoro  (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of kinship, community, and friendship, and they do commerce in fish, condiments, and tubers. The group members are on their first loan.

Ms. SITAN C., who is in the group, plans on using her loan to buy fish from retailers in Fana for resale on a daily basis. She accepts cash or credit from a customer base composed of women and men. 

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA that will be used to make the loan payments and to help pay for societal ceremonies. The rest of the profits will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy fish

loans.name: Patricia Del Socorro

texts.es: La señora Patricia M. , tiene la edad de 32 años , habitante del municipio de Nindiri, junto a su compañero de vida el cual trabaja para apoyarla con  los gastos del hogar , ellos tienen dos hijos que estudian su primaria , los planes hacia su familia es poder mejor las condiciones de vida ,y construir en su totalidad su vivienda de bloques para poder vivir  mejor , doña Fátima desde hace doce años labora como agricultura , en la siembra de Yuca , la mayor afectación que se le presenta es la falta de agua  , el crédito lo quiere para materiales de siembra tales como , postes , madera de yuca para el cultivo , fertilizantes e insumos .Principalmente la preparación de la tierra .
texts.en: Sra. Patricia M., 32, lives in the town of Nindiri with her partner, a worker, with whom she shares the family's expenses.  They have two children, both still in elementary school.  Sra. Patricia wants to improve the lives of her family and, among other plans, wants to build a better, more solid house.  She has made her living from farming for twelve years.  Her biggest challenge is a lack of water.  She is applying for a loan now so that she can buy supplies for her next crop: wooden posts, fertilizers and the other supplies that she needs to prepare her farm for the next planting.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other supplies for her farming business.

loans.name: Angelica Maria

texts.es:
En San Ignacio de la  parroquia Colon de la ciudad de Portoviejo cada quince días se reúnen los socios del Banco Comunal San Ignacio De Colon. Lugar conocido por su gente trabajadora y dedicada a la agricultura y la ganadería.
 
En este lugar conocimos a la señora Angélica, tiene 28 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene tres hijos de 12, 11 y 3 años, el mayor estudia en colegio y el otro en escuela. El marido es mecánico automotriz. 

Es una ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos se dedica a la venta de ropa por catalogo. Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta. Trabaja los fines de semana, ya que ella tiene que cuidar a su pequeño hijo y también cuida un sobrino por el cual su hermana le paga un sueldo. Los fines de semana ella visita a sus clientes con la finalidad de venderles o cobrarles los productos entregados, nos cuenta que tiene muchos clientes que le realizan sus pedidos ya que les da facilidades de pago. Lleva dos años  que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones de damas y ropa de todo tipo. Este es el tercer ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque sus compañeras son muy responsables.
 
Su sueño es tener una distribuidora.
texts.en:
In San Ignacio in the parish Colon in the city of Portoviejo, the members of the Communal Bank "San Ignacio De Colon" meet every fortnight.  The place is known for its hard-working people dedicated to agriculture and livestock.
 
Here we met Angelica, who is 28 years old and maintains a common law relationship with which she has three boys, ages 12, 11 and 3 years old.  The oldest is in middle school and the other one is in elementary school.  Her spouse is an auto mechanic.

Angelica is a homemaker who sells clothing by catalog for her own income.  Her method is selling door to door. She works weekends, and she has to care for her young son and nephew, for which her sister pays her a salary. On weekends she visits her clients in order to sell or collect payment for the goods delivered.  She says she has many customers who place their orders because it gives them easy terms.  Angelica has been in this business for 2 years and is doing very well.

The requested loan is to buy women's pants and clothing of all kinds. This is her third cycle in the communal bank and she likes it because her partners are very responsible.  Her dream is to have a distributor.

loans.use: to buy women's pants and clothing of all kinds.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is 29 years old, married and has four children. Two of her children study while the others are less than four years of age and have not started their education yet.
Sonia's husband sells milk. He has two buffalo and three cows at home. He milks them twice a day and sells the milk to customers in his community. His rates are reasonable, which is why he has a good number of customers in his area. In order to financially support her husband, Sonia sews clothes. She is very good at her work and receives a good number of orders every month. She also carries out her responsibilities as a housewife very well. Sonia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband so that he can buy another buffalo to increase milk productivity and sales. He has been operating this business for the past 20 years and Sonia hopes that an investment will bring more profits to him.

loans.use: to buy another buffalo.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer.

Ama sells plantain, cassava, palm fruits and small green garden eggs at Elmina. She has done this for eight years. Ama assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. 

She will use the loan to purchase palm fruits, plantain and other items to sell. Ama plans to reinvest her profits back into the business.

loans.use: to purchase palm fruits, plantain and other items to sell.

loans.name: Goderdzi

texts.en:
Goderdzi comes from village Rokiti, West Georgia. He is 44 years old and lives with his wife Tamila and 4-year-old daughter, Ani. Goderdzi works in local shop as a worker producing doors and windows. Along with his main job, he is leading the agricultural business of the family. In particular, the family has a small pig farm with 1 pig. They sell piglets in the village. Goderdzi also owns small plot of land where maize is grown. Harvested corn is used on the farm for feeding the pig and piglets. Though Goderdzi and Tamila work hard, their income is still very low and the family is still regarded as living below the poverty line. For this reason, they get social assistance from the state. Total average monthly income of the family, including government’s assistance, is 570 GEL. 

Goderdzi requested credit for 2 purposes. He will purchase fertilizers for the plot in order to increase the amount and the quality of harvest. With the largest part of the credit, Goderdzi plans to expand an existing pigsty building. The expanded building will allow him to add one more pig to the farm. The income from piglet sales will be doubled. 

In the future, Goderdzi plans to use increased income for improving family living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for pigsty expansion and fertilizers for the plot of land

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan is 59 and married. He has a small piggery in their backyard. From this business he is earning an average of P12,000 every four months of selling his fattened pigs. He has been doing this type of business for four years now. 

His wife works as a dressmaker to help him earn an income for their daily needs. Juan is asking for a loan of P10,000 to buy feed for his pigs. He dreams of growing his business to earn a bigger income so they can repair their house. It was destroyed by typhoon "Juan" (the international name of this storm was "Megi")last year.

loans.use: to buy feed for his pigs

loans.name: Azucena Del Carmen

texts.es:
Azucena, vive con sus hijos y sus nietos,  tiene una venta D. semilla D. marañón, dicho negocio surgió por iniciativa D. su esposo quien lo hace desD. 21 años.
Actualmente ella solicita un préstamo para la compra D. semilla, esta compra le ayudara para tener un mejor inventario para sus ventas y ampliar su negocio.
Ella quiere a traves del prestamo mejorar el negocio y sus ingresos para satisfacer las necesidades D. la familia, ya que se considera una persona emprendedora y con buena moral D. pago.
texts.en: Azucena lives with her children and grandchildren. She sells cashews, a business her husband started 21 years ago. Currently she is requesting a loan to purchase more cashews, which will help improve her inventory so her sales and business expand. Through this loan, Azucena wants to improve her business and her income so she can meet the needs of her family. She considers herself to be an enterprising person with good repayment morals.

loans.use: to purchase cashews.

loans.name: Alinyikira Womens Association Mutundwe Group

texts.en:
40-year-old Resty has been plying her poultry business for the past 10 years. The happily married mother of five says she began this business out of her her own enterprise. The lucrative business nature and high demand for chicken in Kampala, where she operates from is what precipitated her decision to join.
