She says influence from close family and friends also contributed to her decision. Prior to that, she was involved in mostly odd jobs in and around Kampala, principally working in the decoration business.

Weekly she says this business generates gross sales revenue to the tune of Uganda shillings 50,000. Her optimism is high however. She says with this Kiva loan, her business prospects will get that improved lease on life that she has invariably wanted.

She plans to use her loan to purchase chicken mash and more chickens to resell

loans.use: to purchase chicken mash and more chickens to resell.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is a 34-year-old hardworking gentleman with two children living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dream is to see himself complete his studies and then start up income generating projects. He is currently a radio presenter and has been on this job for five years and his desire is to become a station man. Nicholas needs the loan to pay school fees for himself.

loans.use: To pay school fees.

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel is 49 years old and married with 4 children, all attending school. He has been in farming in his hometown of Litein for 4 years and currently employs one farmhand and produces milk for the local market.

Samwel has made a request for a 50,000 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to help him purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the dairy business will help him pay for the education of his children. He also plans to construct a dairy unit with the income.

He sees scarcity of animal feeds as the common challenge in the business.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Humberto

texts.es:
Humberto es socio del Banco Comunal Solución, tiene 58 años y 6 hijos, pero ahora solo 2 estan a su cargo, es socia D. FINCA Perú desD. hace 10 años.
Humberto tiene una oficina D. inmobiliaria (compra y venta D. casas), también tiene un Internet donD. sacan copias, recuerda que el primer crédito lo utilizó para poder comprar materiales D. escritorio y papel, su tienda era pequeña, siendo socio pudo tener L. Inmobiliaria, y su tienda ahora también es Internet, las capacitaciones le ayudaron mucho, como padre, esposo y negociante, como hombre aprendió muchos valores que le ayudaron a seguir progresando, lo que mas le gusta es que confían en las personas, las capacitaciones. Ahora el préstamo lo utilizará para poder comprar computadoras y materiales D. escritorio. Su meta es poder comprar un carro.
texts.en:
Humberto is a member of the Solución Community Bank. He is 58 years old and has six children, but only two still live at home. He has been a member of FINCA Perú for ten years.

Humberto has a real estate agency (buying and selling houses). He also has an Internet station and makes photocopies. He remembers that he used his first loan to buy office materials and paper for his small store. As a Bank member he was able to obtain his real estate agency. The training programs have helped him as a father, husband, and businessman, and he has learned many worthwhile things which have helped him to make progress. He most enjoys the trust that people place in him and the training programs. 

Now he will use the loan to buy computers and office supplies. His goal is to be able to buy a car.

loans.use: to buy computers and office supplies

loans.name: Mubariz

texts.en: Mubariz is 43 years old and a married man with two children. He owns a grocery store and provides for his family with the revenue generated by the store. Mubariz is requesting a loan of 1500 AZN to increase his stock of foodstuffs. Mubariz is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices, and push every once in a while to achieve his goal of becoming a successful entrepreneur. One of his dreams is to expand his business, save some money, and support his family. His current profit from this business is 150 USD. Mubariz has already shown himself to be a good client with a positive credit history.

loans.use: to purchase more food stuffs to meet customer demand.

loans.name: Miguel Omar

texts.es:
El señor Miguel Omar tiene 45 años de edad y se dedica al negocio de servicio de transporte Taxi, tiene 3 años de haber iniciado con su negocio, su unidad esta asignada a un centro comercial de la ciudad capital, miles de personas visitan este centro comercial y que necesitan los servicios de Miguel.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de repuestos para el motor de su taxi,  actualmente no esta trabajando y necesita su unidad para generar ingresos para cubrir la alimentación y los estudios de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Miguel Omar is 45 years old and his business is the provision of taxi services. He started his business 3 years ago and his unit is assigned to a shopping centre in the capital city. Thousands of people visit the shopping centre and require Miguel's services.

The loan will be used to purchase spare parts for the motor of his taxi. He current is not work and he needs his unit to generate and income and to cover the nutrition and educational expenses of his children.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the motor of his taxi.

loans.name: Alejandro

texts.es:
Alejandro de 25 años de edad, es soltero, reside en casa de sus padres, la cual no cuenta con servicios básicos, ubicada  en la zona rural del distrito de Tambogrande que pertenece al departamento de Piura. Es una zona agrícola, ganadera y artesana.

El cuenta con un terreno agrícola en donde suele sembrar mango y limón, ya tiene 5 años de experiencia en esta actividad y durante este tiempo ha llegado a conocer mucho sobre el manejo de estos cultivos. Los ingresos que percibe de estas actividades los utiliza para solventar sus gastos diarios personales. También cría y comercializa ganado ovino.

Alejandro desea comprar fertilizantes para así brindar mantenimiento a su terreno de cultivo para instalar nuevas plantaciones y alimento balanceado para sus ovejas. De esta manera obtendrá una buena cosecha. Para lograr su objetivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Alejandro, 25, is single living in his parents’ house which lacks basic utilities and is located in the rural part of Tambogrande District that belongs to Piura Department.  This zone is noted for farming, animal husbandry and crafts making.

He has a parcel of farmland where he tends to plant mangoes and lemons.  He has five years’ experience in this line of work and he has learned quite a bit about managing these crops over this time.  Income he gets from these activities is used to cover his daily personal expenses.  He also raises sheep to sell.

Alejandro wants to buy fertilizer for crop maintenance and because he wants to start new plantings and also to buy nutritionally balanced feed for his sheep.  This way he will obtain a good harvest.  To reach his objective he has seen the need to ask Edpyme Alternativa for a 500 new sol loan.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and feed for his sheep.

loans.name: Indolesa

texts.en:
Indolesa is from Calamba, Misamis Occidental.  She is 56 years old, married and has three children. 

To make a living, Indolesa runs a general store, selling a variety of food and home used products such as soft drinks, cigarettes, shampoo, soap and more, in the local community. 

Indolesa has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month.

Indolesa is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. 

In 2011, Indolesa joined GDMPC to access financial services to improve her business and living situation. 

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to create a reserve for future emergencies.				.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offerings.

loans.name: Marife

texts.en: Marife is 35 years old and lives in Esperanza, Ramon Magsaysay, Zamboanga del Sur. Marife is married. She has had a vegetable farm for 10 years. She requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to purchase fertilizer and pesticide for her farm. Marife has been a member of Kiva's partner, PMPC, for 2 years. In the future, she hopes that she can improve her living standards and earn more than she needs for her farm.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pesticide for her farm

loans.name: Hilda Rosa

texts.es:
Hilda es socia del Banco Comunal “Brisas del Lago”  ubicado en la provincia y departamento de Puno, tiene 72 años de edad, está casada y tiene 5 hijos independientes.  Cuenta con educación secundaria.

Trabaja desde hace dos años con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos, su primer préstamo fue por la suma de S/. 500.00 nuevo soles, dinero que invirtió en su negocio de venta de artesanías. Actualmente se dedica a la venta de bisutería.

Solicitará un nuevo préstamo por la suma de S/. 1000.00 nuevo soles, préstamo que invertirá en la compra de productos de belleza, joyas, prendas de vestir y mercadería de higiene.  En el negocio le ayuda su hija.

La señora desea agrandar el negocio y mejorarlo para conseguir mayores ganancias.
 
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es la facilidad del préstamo, el compañerismo, el ahorro y sus utilidades.
texts.en:
Hilda is a member of the communal bank, Brisas del Lago, or “Lake Breezes,” located in the Puno department and province. She is 72 and married with three grown children. She has a secondary school education. 

She has worked for two years with the Manuela Ramos Movement. Her first loan was for 500 Nuevos Soles, money that she invested in her artisan business. Her current business is selling costume jewelry. 

She is requesting a new loan for 1,000 Nuevos Soles to invest in beauty products, jewelry, clothing articles, and hygiene products. Her daughter helps her with the business. 

She wants to grow her business and improve it to have better earnings. 

What she likes best about the communal bank is the ease of the loans, the camaraderie, the savings, and its usefulness.

loans.use: purchase beauty products, jewelry, clothing, and hygiene products.

loans.name: Laurente

texts.en:
Laurente is from the village of Gata Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 43 years old. Laurente is married and has four school-aged children.

To make a living, Laurente owns and operates a motorcycle transport service. Laurente has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Laurente is requesting a loan of 45,000 PHP which will be used to purchase an additional motorcycle.

In 2004, Laurente joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase an additional motorcycle.

loans.name: Hue

texts.en:
Mrs Hue is  taking this loan out for her daughter, student Tuyet.  Hoping to be a vet Tuyet has gained a place at Hanoi Agricultural University.  Her tuition will last five years and her graduation will be in 2016.  

She hopes to find a good job in the pet service center in her community.  To obtain this target, she is studying hard to get good results.  Currently, she wants to borrow a loan of 10,206,000 Vietnam dong to pay for her education fees.

loans.use: to pay for her daughters education fees.

loans.name: Jose Rafael

texts.es:
Jose es una persona que se ha caracterizado por ser muy trabajador y siempre querer ofrecer a sus hijos una mejor calidad de vida. Jose es un padre soltero que tiene a su cargo sus 2 hijos debido a que la madre de sus hijos los abandonó hace un tiempo. Jose siempre les ha querido ofrecer a sus hijos una educación de calidad y mayores oportunidades de progreso. Jose se dedica desde los 12 años de edad a la fabricación de sillas mecedoras, la cual hace con partes de madera y cabuyas de mimbre. Gracias a la buena calidad de sus productos, Jose ha podido captar muy buenos clientes, lo que le garantiza muy buenas ventas. Con el ánimo de atender un gran pedido que le ha hecho un cliente, Jose espera que un préstamo le brinde la oportunidad de acceder a la compra de madera e insumos como pegantes, clavos y mimbre, para fabricar un gran pedido que le ha hecho un cliente.

Jose espera que de esta manera sus ingresos aumenten considerablemente y pueda ofrecerles a sus 2 hijos una educación de mejor calidad que la que pueden acceder actualmente. Además Jose espera que su negocio crezca y se consolide en el sector de modo que pueda generar empleo para las personas más necesitadas.

loans.use: Compra de madera e insumos como pegantes, clavos y mimbre, para fabricar un gran pedido que le ha hecho un cliente.

loans.name: Gladis Del Carmen

texts.es:
Gladis, es madre soltera de 2 dos hijos de 15 y 10 años de edad, actualmente se encuentran estudiando en la escuela, su esposo los abandonó y por eso ella desempeña el rol de padre y madre; ella estudio hasta sexto grado.

Gladis, desde muy pequeña se ha dedicado a los oficios domésticos en su casa y en otras casas, ahora elabora antojitos típicos para vender como tamales, yuca frita, pastelitos de carne, helados, entre otros, pues es una actividad muy provechosa para ella y es de donde obtiene ingresos económicos para ella y para sus hijos y también se dedica a la agricultura junto a sus hijos.

Gladis, necesita el préstamo para colocar una pequeña tienda de productos de la canasta básica como frijoles, aceite, azúcar, arroz, entre otros.

Gladis, sueña con tener una tienda con muchos productos; y construir un cuarto para sus hijos.

loans.use: para colocar una pequeña tienda de productos de la canasta básica como frijoles, aceite, azúcar, arroz, entre otros.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa owns a small food market very well situated on a main street. Elsa started the store with a family member who helped her with $100. At first she only sold candy and snacks, but she has slowly evolved into a small groceries market. Elsa will use her loan in order to continue to invest in new items like dairy products and canned goods. She is sure that with the loan her business activity will increase and she will bring in more profits. Elsa has been divorced for about 10 years. She has a son that still lives at home. She completely depends on the business to meet the needs of the household.

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: She wants to invest in goods for her store

loans.name: Albina

texts.en:
Alvina plants rice and corn on her farm. She lives on the land with her husband and three children. She was born in Baba and has been involved in rice production for her entire life. She hopes to invest the loan in fertilizer and the rental of machinery to work the lands. She is hoping that, with the profits, she can finish constructing her home which was left incomplete. She works her part of the land on her own, with little help from her husband who has a separate plot that he rents. She works primarily to educate and feed her children.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana-producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large multinational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soybeans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain, there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soybeans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice farming

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase stock for his shop and start a kiosk

loans.name: Lang

texts.en: Mrs. Lang M., 35, and her husband, 45, live in the Prey Veng Province of Cambodia. Her husband grows vegetables and works as a fisherman, earning $10 a day. Lang M. sells the vegetables that her husband grows and earns $8 a day. Lang is requesting this loan so that she and her husband can build a house. She is a hard working woman, who one day hopes to own her own stall at the market.

loans.use: To build a house

loans.name: Bimuborak

texts.en:
Bimuborak B. has been engaged in business for over 5 years. Her business is to sew national Tadjik mattresses. Her business is located in the service center Navruz. Bimuborak with her two business partners rented one room for their activity 5 years ago.

The process of making mattresses includes four steps: sewing fabric into a long sack, spreading it out on the preparing cotton, putting cotton in the long sack and sewing it with stitch (2 cm) by hand. On one mattress they do 6 or 8 lines of stitches. Making one mattress requires one day. All of them make their mattress separately of each other. Then they give their products to the market for sale. Since ancient times this kind of business is in high demand because it is tradition to give your daughter several (10-12) mattresses with pillows when she is going to get married.

Presently their workshop is one of the known workshops in Khujand and today they sew mattresses according to orders of clients. They have a great number of orders in the wedding period (June-November). To purchase several kinds of fabric for her mattresses she is requesting $1200 for 14 months.

loans.use: Bimuborak would like to buy more fabric to sew and make her traditional Tadjik mattresses often sent with a daughter for her wedding gift.

loans.name: Elena Isabel

texts.es:
Sra. Elena is a member of the Amigos Marcarinos ("Marcara-Area Friends") community bank. She raises and sells "cuyes" (a guinea pig-like animal, native to Peru). Her shop is located in her house in the "distrito" of Marcara in northern Peru. She sells the cuyes in the nearby city of Huaraz, some 30 minutes from Marcara, and to tourists who come to Marcara. She especially values her role as homemaker and she takes special care to tend to her family.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.200 (200 Peruvian soles or about US$66), to be repaid in 4 installments, she's purchased breeding cuyes so that she can improve the stock of the rest.

Sra. Elena, 39, a thriving businesswoman, aspires to keep on growing her business with help from Manuela Ramos and her family. Thanks to her husband's many skills, as gasfitter, electrician, etc., he has many short-term opportunites to work. Their two incomes allow them to plan a better future for their two young children.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Elena es socia del Banco Comunal Amigos Marcarinos, se dedica a la crianza y venta de cuyes (animales caseros oriundos del Perú), su local se encuentra en su domicilio ubicado en el Distrito de Marcara, Provincia de Carhuaz, Departamento de Ancash. La venta de cuyes la hace en la ciudad de Huaraz, localidad que está a 30 minutos de Marcara, también los vende directo a los Recreos turísticos de su Localidad, en su afán de sobresalir como madre se esfuerza mucho para casar adelante a su familia.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 200.00 ($ 66) el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, ha comprado cuyes reproductores, para mejorar la calidad de sus otros cuyes.

La señora Elena tiene 39 años, prospera negociante, aspira seguir incrementando su negocio con el apoyo de Manuela Ramos y su familia, gracias a que su esposo desempeña varios oficios, como gasfitería, electricista, tiene varios trabajos que son eventuales, ambos ingresos le permite sacar adelante a sus dos pequeños hijos.

loans.use: Buy breeding animals.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester owns a retail shop where she sells new clothing as well as dry staples such as sugar, salt, rice, maize flour, etc. In most retail stores, these staples are there biggest sellers and have the most profit potential. The problem is sometimes almost every fourth or fifth store sells the same item, so competition is heated. Often the difference between success and failure in this type of business is your personality.

Ester has a very pleasant personality. She is 30 years old and married with 5 children. She also sells new clothing that appeals to young women and their children. With her loan, she plans to add more clothes to her store. Her dream is to one day build her own home and to educate her children so that they can go to university.

loans.use: Ester plans to use her loan to buy more clothes for her store.

loans.name: Morufat

texts.en: Morufat A. is 29 years old, married with 4 children, and hails from Araromin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a fashion designer and sells clothes. She has been in her business since 1999 and needs the loan of $275 to get more clothing and cloth to be sold.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Zaur

texts.en:
A. Zaur is 30-year old farmer who has been breeding calves and selling milk since 2003. He lives with his family in a small village of Saatli Region. He is unemployed, and farming is the only one source of income in this family.

Mr. Zaur tries very hard, and meat and milk are in high demand all across Azerbaijan. People in Azerbaijan use meat in almost in every meal. Since last year, the prices for these products increased by five times, and now, keeping a family in good conditions is not very easy. Mr. Zaur decided to expand his business and purchase three additional calves for breeding and a fodder. For this purpose, he applied for $1100 USD.

loans.use: To purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Rosa Mary

texts.en:
Rosa Mary Z. D. runs a small market in the tropical city of Pucallpa, Ucayali. At her market she sells clothing, shoes, and tools. She started her market one year ago after running a bodega for many years. When the bodega didn’t work out she changed her focus and she now has a successful business. Rosa is 32 years old, single, and has two children. She is happy to have her business and a supportive family that helps her with her children. She works and saves daily so that one day she can send her children to study at a university.

A member of the community bank Juan Zaplana Belliza, Rosa is requesting a loan of s/1500 to repay over 6 months to buy more clothing and shoes to restock her store.

loans.use: to buy more clothing and shoes.  The loan will be vital to restock her store.

loans.name: Marisol

texts.en: Marisol, hard-working and multifaceted entrepreneur and mother of three school-going children, owns a small lottery bank and sells shoes, tennis shoes and other goods to the women of her community.  She has been selling these goods for more than ten years. Marisol explains that it’s a very hard task to keep up three children and have to pay the rental of the house.  Nonetheless, she says she’ll keep doing her best to provide good education to them. With her loan, the entrepreneur will buy more goods to continue satisfying her clientele’s need and increase her revenue.

loans.use: To buy shoes and tennis shoes for a small business.

loans.name: Sergey

texts.en:
Sergey is married and has a teenage daughter. He’s a businessman from Ivano-Frankivsk, Western Ukraine where he offers transportation services. His taxi business is the only source of income for his family. Sergey is very responsible and modest and has a good reputation among other taxi drivers. He has promptly repaid all loans he has received from “Nadiya Ukraine”. He uses an economical, diesel vehicle for his taxi and, after fuel costs, he is able to bring in around $50 in daily profit. Having a flexible schedule and being willing to provide transportation services all over Ukraine has helped Sergey get many loyal clients.

Sergey is requesting a loan of 2000 Grivnas to help repair his vehicle and make it more reliable. A newer running gear system in the car will give Sergey the opportunity to travel to other destinations, change some of his regular itineraries and expand his business. Not only will this help his business but it will also give his family a better quality of life. One day Sergey is hoping to buy his own car. He believes his transportation business will help him achieve this goal.

loans.use: To repair taxi

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is the wife of M. A.. ( Baji is an Urdu term meaning 'elder sister'.) They have been married for the last 30 years. The couple has five children; two sons and three daughters. She is a housewife and prefers to stay at home. Her husband is a salesman and sells sewing machines in various locations. Parveen is applying for a loan so her husband can expand his business.

She has three women in her loan group. Ramazan baji wants a loan to buy vehicle tires; Razia baji would like money to expand her paint shop and Asia baji wants a loan to increase the amount of clothes she can sell.

The loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand a sewing machine sales business

loans.name: Sarakognouma (Bon Remboursement) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Sarakognouma group are married women with an average age of 40 and an average of 6 children. They live in extended traditional families with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the village of Djinina, Sub-prefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

This group deals in: charcoal, condiments and various small items such as peanuts, guinea fowl eggs, epinares, baobab leaves, etc.

They met because of professional reasons, because they live near each other, or are relatives. In searching for business capital, the members of the Sarakognouma group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso with whom they have just received a first loan. Sarakognuoma are a group of retailers, plain and simple, who stock up on condiments exclusively on weekly market days in Fana, buying from wholesalers who come from Bamako, Ségou, Dioila, or from those living in Fana itself. They purchase smaller items in the village and surrounding areas or get them in the countryside (by harvesting them) or collect guinea fowl eggs along the edges of the fields. They sell essentially out of their houses in the village, retail and on a cash basis and also on credit.

The members of the Sarakognouma group intend to buy with this loan: 50 kg of condiments (composed of various sorts used in preparing dishes) at 1500 FCFA the kilogram and re-selling in small quantities making a monthly average profit margin of 30,000 FCFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan and to invest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Sarakognouma sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 40 ans et 6 enfants Elles vivent dans des familles élargies traditionnelles avec leurs maris, coépouses et enfants dans le village de Djinina sous préfecture de Fana (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali)

Ce groupe exerce le commerce de : charbon de bois de condiments et divers petits articles : arachides, œufs de pintade, epinares, feuilles de baobab etc.

Elles se sont connues par des relations d’ordre professionnel de voisinage et de parenté. Dans leurs recherches de fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe Sarakognouma ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles viennent de bénéficier d’un premier prêt. Sarakognuoma est vraiment un groupe de pures détaillantes qui s’approvisionnent en condiments exclusivement les jours de marchés hebdomadaires de Fana auprès de grossistes qui viennent de Bamako Ségou Dioila et résident à Fana même .Quant aux divers elles s’approvisionnent sur place au village et environs soit en brousse (activité de cueillettes) soit le ramassage des œufs de pintades au abords des champs. Elles vendent essentiellement à domicile (au village) en détail au comptant et aussi à crédit.

Les membres du groupe Sarakognouma comptent acheter avec ce prêt : 50 kg de condiments (composés de différentes sortes toutes dans la préparation des plats alimentaires) à 1500FCFA le kilogramme et revendus à détail dégage une marge bénéficiaire mensuelle et moyenne de 30000FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir dans les activités.

loans.use:
Purchase and re-sale of diverse items

Achat vente d’articles divers

loans.name: Bupe I.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Bupe N.. She is married and has three children aged one, three, and six. In 2006, Bupe established her butchery business. Working six days a week and 13 to 16 hours a day, she earns about 120 USD every month. She is assisted by her husband in the shop. Bupe requires a loan in order to expand and renovate her business. In the future, Bupe plans to open another business. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand and renovate her business

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.ru: Рахимова Гульбахор жительница района Хуросон.Возраст 43 года,замужем, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее.Клиентка занимается куплей продажей сельхоз.животных.Она покупает на местном рынке молодых барашкев,откармливает их и продает по выгодной ей цене. Занимается этим бизнесом более 3 лет. На доход от эттого бизнеса она содержит она содержит свою семью.Так как муж клиентки временно не работает.В данный момент клиентка планиурет  купить 3 баранов.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 10 месяцев
texts.en:
Gulbahor R. is a resident of the Khuroson district. 43-years-old, she is married and has four children. She attended secondary school, and now engages in the buying and selling of farm animals. She buys young lambs locally, fattens and sells them for a profit. Gulbahor has been in this business for three years, and on the income from this endeavor she supports her family since her husband is temporarily unemployed. At present, she intends to purchase three sheep, and plans to repay the loan within ten months.

Translated from Russian by Joyce K., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of three lambs

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María C. Huamán is a member of community bank, Anabella at FINCA Perú. She sells groceries at fairs and on the street 3 times a day.

She plans to invest her loan of 1000 soles into purchasing corn, drinks, sugar, ham and noodles. She plans to continue saving and use earnings to help educate her son and to continue improving her grocery business.
texts.en:
María C. Huamán is a member of community bank, Anabella at FINCA Perú. She sells groceries at fairs and on the street 3 times a day.

She plans to invest her loan of 1000 soles into purchasing corn, drinks, sugar, ham and noodles. She plans to continue saving and use earnings to help educate her son and to continue improving her grocery business.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She plans to invest her loan of 1000 soles into purchasing corn, drinks, sugar, ham and noodles.

loans.name: Gudelia

texts.es:
La señora Gudelia, socia del BC Las Trabajadoras, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. Tiene 45 años de edad y vive con su esposo y dos de sus 3 hijos que están estudiando y aún dependen de ella. 

Se dedica a la venta de todo tipo de videos, películas, musicales entre otros. Vende de manera ambulatoria y generalmente está en la puerta del mercado central. Complementa su negocio con la venta de gaseosas y mercería.   

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,700, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará videos (películas y musicales) actuales para asegurar sus ventas, también comprará gaseosas de diferentes marcas, tamaños y sabores, así como también mercería  para poder surtir su negocio. 

Gudelia manifiesta que Manuela Ramos es un apoyo, tanto para ella y compo para su familia, y también para otras mujeres emprendedoras. Trabaja duro cada día porque quiere crecer en su negocio y ver a sus hijos profesionales.
texts.en:
Gudelia is a member of the group BC Las Trabajadoras. She lives in the region of San Martin, a province of Mariscal Caceres, a district of Juanjui. She is 45 years old and lives with her husband and 3 sons who are studying and still depend on her.

She works selling all types of videos; films, musicals among others. She is a wandering saleswoman and generally sells in the entrance of the central market. She complements her business selling fizzy drinks and haberdashery.

With the loan of S/ 1700, which she will repay over a period of 6 months, she will buy recent videos (films and musicals) to assure their sales, as well as buying different brands, sizes and flavors of fizzy drink, as well as haberdashery, so that she can stock her business.

Gudelia shows that Manuela Ramos is a form of support, as much for her as for her family, and also for other industrious women. She works hard each day because she wants to see her business grow and her kids become professionals.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy videos (films and musicals), fizzy drinks and haberdashery/Comprará videos (películas y musicales), gaseosas y mercería.

loans.name: Tausi Group

texts.en:
Meshack Rameck, age 34, is married with one son of 11 years. He has a chicken business which he started in 2003. He works daily from 8am until 6pm and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $238.

This will be Meshack’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the first loan to increase on the stock of his chicken and has paid the loan back successfully. He now hopes for a new loan to expand his chicken business.

Meshack will share this loan with subgroup A of the Tausi group. The subgroup has seven members, who run shops and sell charcoal and food. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Meshack is second from left, standing

loans.use: To buy more chickens for sale.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
La señora Margarita, socia del BC “MUJERES AUDACES”,  vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, se dedica a la venta de comida tipo menú y desarrolla su negocio en un local alquilado en una de las calles céntricas de la ciudad a donde acuden gran cantidad de clientes por la buena sazón y trato que les brinda. 

Con este crédito de S/. 2,000, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará los insumos como arroz, azúcar en saco, aceite en galón, fideos, verduras, carnes y otros insumos que necesita para la preparación de sus platos a ofertar a sus clientes. 
La señora Margarita tiene 47 años de edad, vive con su  esposo y con sus dos hijos que cursan estudios superiores y quienes la impulsan a esforzarse cada día más. Desea para el futuro contar con su restaurante bien arreglado porque hace poco que está en ese lugar.
texts.en:
Margarita, a member of the “Bold Women” communal bank, lives in the San Martín region, in the province and district of Moyobamba. She works selling traditional food as part of a fixed menu, and her business is run out of a rented space on one of the main streets in the city where many customers come for the delicious flavor and the way she treats them. With this loan of 2,000 soles ($675), which she will repay over 6 months, she will buy ingredients such as rice, sacks of sugar, gallons of oil, noodles, vegetables, meat, and other ingredients that she needs to prepare her dishes to sell to her customers. Margarita is 47 years old and lives with her husband and two children who are in secondary school. Her children inspire her to keep working every day. In the future she would like to have a nicer restaurant because she has not been in her current space for very long.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, sacks of sugar, gallons of oil, noodles, vegetables, meats, and other ingredients

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es: Nancy tiene 35 años de edad, es madre de 3 hijos que la apoyan mucho y una pareja a quien ama y siempre la anima a seguir trabajando por sus metas. Esta pareja se dedica al transporte, su esposo maneja el motocarro que es de Nancy por toda la ciudad haciendo servicio de taxi y ella administra todas las ganancias. Adicionalmente vende comida por las noches en las afuera de su casa. Con ambos negocios y las ganancias de los mismos están sosteniendo a la familia y pagando los gastos educativos de sus hijos. Es la primera vez que Nancy recurre a MFP en busca de un crédito, comprometiéndose a pagar de manera puntual, la cantidad que está solicitando es para el mantenimiento de su motocarro, y también para la construcción de un kiosco para su negocio de venta de comida.
texts.en:
Nancy is 35 years old and the mother of three children who support her a great deal. She has a partner who she loves, and who always encourages her to continue working toward her goals. This couple dedicates themselves to transportation, her husband driving the motocar owned by Nancy throughout the city providing a taxi service. She administers their earnings. Additionally, she sells food in the evenings outside of their house. With both businesses, and earnings from each, they are supporting the family and paying for their children’s educations. This is the first time that Nancy turns to MFP in search of a loan, promising to make her loan payments on time. The amount she is requesting is to maintain the motocar, and also to build a kiosk for her food sales business.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To maintain the motocar.

loans.name: Umarboy

texts.ru: Умарбой мужчина который кридитуется уже пятый год в Микроинвесте, займ берёт для поддержки бизнеса купли продажи скота.Умарбой сам закупает скот и откормив его продаёт на рынке.С помощью чего и ведёт свою жизнь.У него большая семья.Семеро детей,из которых двое уже семейные , имеют свои семьи.А пятеро ещё на иждивении Умарбоя.По уходу за скотом ему помогает его жена.Очередной кредит Умар хочет получить для увеличения численности своих баранов.
texts.en:
Umarboy is a man who has been taking out loans at MicroInvest for five years. He takes a loan to support his business of buying and selling cattle. Umarboy buys the cattle and then resells it on the market after feeding and growing it. He lives with the help of this business. He has a large family of seven children two of which are already married and have their own families. Other five are still his dependents. Umarboy's wife helps him look after the livestock. This next loan Umarboy wants to use to increase the headcount of his sheep.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To incrase headcount of sheep

loans.name: Kolorita

texts.en:
Kolorita J. is 57 years old and is married with a husband who works in business. She has 4 children who all attend school. Kolorita currently sells sugar and alcohol and is requesting a loan to expand her business. With the extra profits attained through her loan she hopes to build a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. All are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which targets returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To expand her business in order to build a shop

loans.name: Amelinda

texts.en:
Amelinda B. grows pigs for a living. She started her business 2 years ago and is convinced that hog raising is one of the most profitable business to do. Before, she worked on a farm and got paid for all her services, but she was not content to just work and get paid. She wanted to have a business of her own to be able to save money for her future family. She is 25 years old and still single.

Amelinda is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy feeds to grow her pigs. She will also use some of the loan to buy additional piglets to grow her little piggery.

CEVI is a nonprofit organization that helps people, especially the poor, to start and have their own business. CEVI provides credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to all their clients.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and additional piglets

loans.name: Zenaida Marcionila

texts.es:
La señora Zenaida Marcionila A. D. G. tiene 70 años y pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres del Mañana, vive en el distrito D. Agallpampa D. la provincia D. Otuzco del departamento D. La Libertad Perú.
Estudió hasta cuarto grado D. educación primaria, pero no pudo continuar sus estudios debido a la falta D. apoyo económico D. sus familiares.
Como era costumbre los matrimonios se arreglaban por convenio entre los padres D. los novios,  a ella le arreglaron el matrimonio a los 16 años y tiene 12 hijos.
Actualmente venD. cerveza y fruta, recuerda que anteriormente tenía negocios múltiples.
Con su primer crédito D. 300 soles que canceló en cuatro cuotas, compró gaseosa y cerveza.
Con este crédito D. 1,000 soles que cancelará en 4 cuotas comprará cerveza para venderla en la fiesta patronal D. su región.
Zenaida sueña con arreglar su casa para tener a todos sus hijos con ella.
texts.en:
Mrs. Zenaida Marcionila A. D. G. is seventy years old and belongs to the Communal Bank of Women of Tomorrow. She lives in the district of Agallpampa in the province of Otuzco, department of La Libertad, Peru. She studied until the fourth graD. of primary school, but was unable to continue her studies due to lack of financial support from her family. As was customary, marriages were arranged by agreement between the parents of the briD. and groom, and for her they arranged a marriage when she was sixteen. She has twelve children. Currently she sells beer and fruit, and remembers that previously she had multiple businesses. With her first loan of 300 soles, which she repaid in four installments, she bought soda and beer. With this loan of 1000 soles, which she will repay in four installments, she will buy beer to sell at the patron saint festival of her region. Zenaida dreams about fixing her house in order to have all her children with her.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy beer to sell at the festival

loans.name: Jose Francisco

texts.es: El señor José Francisco S., tiene la edad de 62 años , habita en el barrio San Francisco , junto a su esposa la cual le apoya con los trabajos agrícolas y las actividades del hogar , ellos tienen cinco hijos , ya todos casados , ellos le apoyan con los gastos del hogar , los planes hacia su familia es poder mejorar los cultivos y poder comprar un terreno , para darle a cada uno de sus hijos partes iguales ; don José desde hace 50 años se dedica a la actividad agrícola , el inicio con sus propios esfuerzos para poder darle alimentos a sus cinco hijos .Con el financiamiento  va a comprar fertilizantes e insumos para mejorar el cultivo y poder tener una buena producción.
texts.en:
Mr. José Francisco S. is 62 years old and lives in the San Franciso district with his wife, who helps him with farm work and running the household. They have five children, all married, who help him with household expenses. His plan for his family is to be able to improve his crops and to be able to buy some land, in order to give each of his children an equal part. José has been farming for 50 years. He began on his own in order to feed his five children. With financing, he is going to buy fertilizers and supplies to improve his crops and to be able to get a good yield.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies and fertilizers to get a good yield.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is married to an army officer, Arthur I., who is 43 years old. They live in Purok (district) Bannauag, Magsaysay, Naguilian, Isabela. They are blessed with one child, Angeline I., who is seven years old. Teresita is proud having a family that is happy and has a strong bond. She hopes that the good relationship in their family remains.

Teresita has been managing a sari-sari store (typical village store) in her village for about ten years. She has been running this store since long before she got married to her husband. Sometimes she has to close her business because her revolving capital has to be used for emergencies. Teresita wants to expand her business so that she does not have to close her store when an unexpected event happens. She is requesting a loan of PHP 9,000 from the lenders.

She believes that there is always a prize in every sacrifice; thus, she is working hard to acquire more prizes in the future. The loan she requested will help a great deal in expanding her business and her family’s life, Teresita added.

loans.use: To use as business capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Estelbina Del Socorro

texts.es:
La señora Estelbina como toda mujer nicaraguense es muy esforzada y trabajadora la cual se dedica a su trabajo de elaboración y venta de alimentos preparados por ella misma en su localidad en la ciudad de Chinandega. 

Ella ha logrado mejorar en parte su condición pasando de vender solamente alimentos a vender bebidas y esto se lo ha debido a Ceprodel el cual le ha beneficiado grandemente. Hoy en día ha solicitado un nuevo crédito para continuar saliendo adelante y así beneficiar a su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Estelbina, as all Nicaraguan women, is very energetic and hard working. She dedicates her time to the preparation and sale of food, which she makes herself at her residence in the city of Chinandega. She has been able to improve her conditions by going from selling only food to also selling beverages. This was made possible by Ceprodel, from which she has benefited a great deal. She is currently requesting a new loan to continue to move forward and benefit her family.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food ingredients.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Business ownership has been a gateway to personal freedom for Pedro. He has worked many jobs in his lifetime, but none other has given him the satisfaction that running his taxi service does. Pedro operates his taxi in Manhattan from 42nd Street and below, driving clients all over New York City, to and from the airports, and sometimes long distances to other cities along the eastern seaboard. He has been married for 30 years, has a grown daughter, and is also a proud grandfather.

The dispatch company for which Pedro operates his taxi requires him to purchase a new vehicle every ten years. Pedro currently drives a 1998 with more than 397,000 miles, so he has come to ACCION USA for a loan to purchase a new vehicle. In addition to allowing him to continue working for his current dispatch company, the new taxi will provide a more comfortable ride for his clients. Pedro is a long-time client of ACCION USA. He has received several loans in the past and has always repaid on time.

He has plans to rent his old taxi to a cousin who can use it with another dispatch service in New York City. Pedro is looking forward to the next ten years with his new taxi. He is thankful to be supported and able to live out his dream of owning a taxi.

video.title: Kiva Entrepreneur Pedro from  United States

loans.use: To buy a newer taxi

loans.name: Suk

texts.en: Suk P. lives in Kompong Chhnang Province and earns a small income by owning and running a small restaurant near her house in which she sells beef soup. Besides selling soup, she and her husband also distill white wine and grow rice. Suk P. has seven children, two of whom are married; three are garment workers in Phnom Penh. Suk P. has applied for a loan for two purposes: to buy a cow and begin raising a small herd of cattle, and buy fertilizer for her rice crop.

loans.use: To buy a cow to begin raising a small herd of cattle

loans.name: Benkadi 6 De (Benkadi  A Tingolé) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe BENKADI 6 de l’association BENKADI A ont une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans, 6 enfants et  vivent tous  dans des familles élargies traditionnelles à TINGOLE  chef lieu d’une commune rurale de la sous-préfecture de FANA, 2ème région administrative  de la république du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’avoir un soutien financier pour la réalisation de leurs activités hivernales. Leurs activités sont axées sur la culture du sorgho et de l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt avec l’institution et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent  acheter, de l’engrais, de l’herbicide, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de sarclage et de labour pour entretenir 26 hectares.
Une partie de leur production est auto consommée et l’autre partie est vendue exclusivement sur les marchés du  village de Marka-Coungo et Fana, après les récoltes, à une clientèle composée généralement de revendeurs venant des grandes villes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30 000FCFA après la campagne.
NB : Penda Konaté est absente de la photo pour des raisons de santé (chute en moto).
texts.en:
The members of the group BENKADI 6 of the association BENKADI A average 45 years of age and 6 children. They all live in traditional extended families in TINGOLE, the seat of a rural community in FANA subprefecture (2nd administrative region of Mali). The group members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of obtaining financial support for carrying out their winter-time work, which revolves around growing sorghum and peanuts. The group is now on its fifth experience with the institution. All the preceding loans were correctly repaid. With this new loan, they intend to buy fertilizer, herbicide, and minor supplies and equipment and to cover the cost of weeding and labor for maintaining 26 hectares. A portion of their production is consumed at home. The other portion is sold after the harvests to customers generally composed of big city retailers exclusively at the marketplaces of Marka-Coungo and Fana. The group members plan on realizing an average profit of 30,000 francs CFA after the planting campaign. Note: Penda Konaté is absent from the photo due to health reasons (motorbike accident).

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, fertilizer, herbicide, weeding and sundry supplies and equipment

loans.name: Evelina

texts.es:
Evelina es socia del Banco Comunal Wiñarisun que significa Crezcamos en quechua.
Evelina es soltera, tiene 42 años y 3 hijos, Evelina vive en el distrito de Quinua en donde vende comida, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de su hijo menor.
Evelina necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido como parte de pago de un terreno para su casa.
Evelina sueña con construir su casa y tener una tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Evelina is a member of the Wiñarisun Village Bank, which means "Let's Grow" in the Quechua language. She is 42, single, and has three children. She lives in the Quinua district, where she sells food on a daily basis with the help of her youngest child. Evelina needs a loan for 1000 soles, which she'll use as partial payment on a lot for her house. She dreams of building her house and having a grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: As partial payment on a lot for her house.

loans.name: Sroeun

texts.en: Mrs. Sroeun G. lives in Khsom village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Ei Rean, are farmers who earn a living by cultivating rice on a plot of land that they own. They do not have enough money to buy the farm supplies they need, so Mrs. Sroeun G. decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer and a pump. She would use the rest of money to buy vegetables to resell in order to earn more income. She is 45 years old and the mother of eight children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another is a farmer.  Of the others, three are enrolled in the local school. The youngest one is just four years old. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and a pump, and also vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji A. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at the resturant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs, cook and sell.

  Keji is 32 years old and is Married with a husband that is a business man. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a lorry.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Ana Gladis

texts.es: Ana Gladis A. V. reside en Candelaria en el departamento de Cuscatlán.  Ana tiene tan solo 20 años de edad, vive con su familia padre y madre. A pesar de ser muy joven Ana siempre ha ayudado a su familia en los negocios, ahora Ana se dedica a la elaboración de puros los que realiza desde su casa, el crédito que solicita es para compra materiales que se utilizan para la elaboración de puros.
texts.en:
Ana Gladis A. V. lives in Candelaria in the Cuscatlán department. Ana is only 20, and she lives with her mother and father. In spite of being very young, Ana has always helped her family in their business. Ana makes cigars in her house. The loan she is asking for is to buy materials to make cigars.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw material

loans.name: Lorence

texts.en: Lorence L., 46, has been providing her neighbors, and even friends abroad, with her home-made cured fish for almost three years now. She lives in Zabarte, Caloocan City. Her 53 year old husband, Ireneo, is an auto electrician. Their only child is still in grade school. Lorence carefully debones bangus (milkfish - the country’s national fish) and cures them for longer shelf life. Her finished products appeal to a lot to her customers so that she always finds herself working overtime to meet their demands. Her cured bangus now reaches her friends overseas at an additional fee for handling. In addition, she also delivers fresh pork meat to her neighbors. Lorence is thankful to the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for providing her with loans which she has used to buy fresh bangus in bulk. She now earns at least P9,000 a month but her earnings sometimes vary depending on the supply of fresh meat and fish and the demand for finished products. Lorence uses her profits to support the daily needs of her family, especially her child’s education. She applied for a new loan of P17,000 from CCT Credit Cooperative. She wishes to come up with an appealing packaging for her cured fish for better marketability. She also wishes that her products qualify for the export standards. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her food preparation business

loans.name: Malika Talash Group

texts.en:
This is Malika Talash group which has four members: Naik Bakat, Leela, Malika and Gul J., all of whom live in district 13 of Kabul, Afghanistan. Naik Bakat is the group leader.

Naik Bakat is 30 years old and lives in a family of six members. She has been a tailor since the Taliban regime and has sewed clothes because at that time they had lots of economic problems. Now, with the Kiva loan, she wants to buy a new sewing machine and wants to start her business in a new direction to support her family members.

Leela is the second member. She wants to take a loan for her husband who has fuel-selling shop. Through its income he supports his family members and his purpose of obtaining the loan is to expand his business

The third member is Mahlika who has a carpet-weaving business. She wants to buy better materials for carpet weaving and wants to support all her family members.

The last member is Gul J. who has quilt-making business. She wants to buy all the necessary materials which she needs for her business.

So they together have requested a group loan of 42,000 Afghani. They would like to say thanks to Kiva lenders who are able to support all entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio C. is from the village of Cabol-anonan, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. He is 70 years old. Rogelio is married and has 7 adult children. 

In 2008, Rogelio joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation.  Rogelio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to for house repair. Rogelio is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to finish the house repair. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Rogelio from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make further improvements to his house. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Lillian

texts.en:
Lillian lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 25 years old and married, and has 3 children, all of whom excel in school.

Lillian sells hair extensions and hair cream to her customers. She has been in this business for 3 years. This is the busy season for her business and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. 

Lillian is a client of Lift above Poverty Organization (LAPO), a Kiva field partner that is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and throughout Africa. She is hoping for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Rma Eloisa

texts.es:
La socia es natural D. la ciudad D. Urcos D. la provincia D. Quispicanchis del departamento del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “Qori Orcco” D. la Asociación Arariwa. El nombre del banco es D. origen D. la lengua Quechua que traducido al español significa “Cerro D. Oro”. Cusco antiguamente, fue la capital del Imperio Inca y una D. las ciudades más importantes del Virreinato del Perú. Declarada Patrimonio D. la Humanidad y capital arqueológica D. América. 

Nuestra socia IRMA tiene 54 años, es madre soltera y tiene tres hijos que ya no dependen D. ella. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el negocio D. venta y compra D. madera D. la ciudad D. Puerto Maldonado y la venta D. tamales (Es un plato típico del Perú echo a base D. maíz blanco). La socia venD. sus tamales en los buses que van al sur del Cusco, desD. las 6 D. la mañana hasta las 5 la tarD.. Ya son varios años que tiene los negocios y le ha ido muy bien, gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más insumos como maíz pelado y manteca para preparar más tamales. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.

La ciudad D. Urcos se encuentra ubicada a 45 km del Cusco siguiendo la carretera asfaltada a Puno, es un pequeño poblado con una hermosa laguna donD., según la leyenda, Huascar lanzó una enorme cadena D. oro para evitar que los españoles se la llevaran.
texts.en:
Irma was born in the city of Urcos, province of Quispicanchis, district of Cusco. She’s a member of the “Qori Orcco” Community Bank, part of the Arariwa Association. The name of the bank comes from the Quechua language, meaning “Golden Hills”. Cusco was once the capital city of the Inca Empire and one of the most important cities of the Peruvian Viceroyalty. The city was declared Patrimony of Humanity and archaeological capital of the Americas. Irma is 54 years old. She’s a single mother of three, although they are all independent now. She divides her time between her household activities and her retail wood store located in Puerto Maldonado and her tamales stand (typical Peruvian dish, maD. of white corn). She sells tamales on the busses that go south of Cusco, from 6am to 5pm. She's been doing this for many years with great success, thanks to her hard work. She’s a working mother and an entrepreneur trying to support her family. She would like to use this loan to purchase more items such are pealed corn and butter to make more tamales. She’s very thankful for this opportunity and she’s committed to fulfill her payments according to schedule. The city of Urcos is located at 45 km from Cusco, following the asphalted road to Puno. It’s a small town with a beautiful lagoon where, according to the legend, Huascar threw a huge golden chain to prevent the Spanish settles to take it away.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase items such are pealed corn and butter to make tamales

loans.name: Sebastián

texts.es:
El Sr. Sebastián G. Z. trabaja para una institución del estado, el es el responsable de mantenimientos y cuido de las instalaciones de dicha institución.

El crédito que solicita lo utilizara para la compra de materiales de construcción como hierro y ladrillos de cuarterón, estos serán utilizados para la elaboración de las cerca de su casa de habitación.

El Sr. Sebastián G. trabaja en esta institución desde hace 13 años, y realiza sus labores desde las 8 de la mañana que es su hora de entrada hasta las 5 de la tarde todos los días de la semana, antes de dedicarse a este trabajo el era comerciante.

El espera que con la compra del hierro y los ladrillos va a completar los materiales para poder construir un muro que rodee sus casa y le des mas seguridad y protección ya que su cerca esta construida de manera rustica y en mal estado.

El Sr. Sebastián es soltero y tiene 4 hijos tres de ellos trabajan por cuenta propia y  la hija menor estudia en la universidad cuyos gastos los costea Don Sebastián.

Este es el cuarto crédito que Don Sebastián tiene con Ceprodel en un periodo de 2 años y dice que dichos créditos le han beneficiado bastante ya que a través de estos a logrado adquirir su muebles y utensilio de trabajo que por cuenta proa se le harían imposible obtenerlos.
texts.en:
Sebastián G. Z. works for a state institution and is responsible for the maintenance and care of the facilities. He plans to use the loan he is requesting to purchase construction materials like iron and bricks to make a fence for his home. Sebastián has worked at the institution for 13 years and works from 8 in the morning until 5 in the evening every day of the week. Before this job he made a living as a merchant. He hopes that the purchase of the iron and bricks will complete the materials he needs to build a fence that surrounds his house and will give him more security and protection since his current fence is in very bad shape. Sebastián is single and has four children, three who work on their own, and his youngest daughter studies at the university thanks to his financial help. This is the fourth loan for Sebastián through Kiva partner Ceprodel over the past two years, and he says that he has greatly benefited from the loan, through which he has been able to acquire furniture and work tools that would've been otherwise impossible to get.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase iron and bricks to make a fence

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en: Concepcion G. runs a general store selling a variety of different products in her community. She is 46 years old, married and has five adult children. She is from the village of Centro 2, Mallig, Isabela. Concepcion has been in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2007, Concepcion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. Concepcion is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This will be her eighth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Awney

texts.en: Awney owns a supermarket in a good area in Gaza and is hoping to increase his sales through a $3000 loan.  He wants to improve the interior of his store as well as buy new products and increase his stock.  He is 49 years-old and has four children that are studying in school with one in college. He is hoping to have enough money to send all his children to college.

loans.use: To enhance his store with new products and a better interior.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 46 year married with four children ages 13 and 22 years.  All her school go to school.  She resides in and owns a five roomed house where she stays with seven people.  She has access to electricity but no piped water.  

She owns a retail shop selling day to day essentials.  On average Betty receives 20 customers a day.  She has been in this business for six years and with MCDT for ten years servicing her eighteenth loan. 

Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication.  Her challenges include customer defaulters and the rainy season because many customers stay away.  Betty wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like soap, salt sacks, sugar and cans of cooking oil.

loans.use: Buy more merchandise like sugar ,salt, soap  for her retail shop.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda M., 59, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Faustino, a carpenter, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store while maintaining a cooked food stall which usually offers breakfast fare and viands.

Yolanda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow eleven times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries needed for her variety store and raw ingredients needed to continue production of her breakfast fare and viands.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her grandchildren’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying groceries needed for her variety store and raw ingredients for her breakfast fare and viands

loans.name: Se

texts.en:
Mr. Se Y., 32 (pictured with his son) and his wife, Mrs. Koeun Hul, 30, have been remarried for ten years and have two children: one daughter, who attends school; and one young son. They live in a village along National Road Number Five, approximately seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Se is a blacksmith, while his wife has been a garment factory worker for twelve years. He wants to buy a motorcycle for commuting because he does not have any means of transportation. Hence, he is asking for a loan of $500 to make the purchase.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike commuting for commuting.

loans.name: Succès Plus Group

texts.en:
Germaine B. is 41 years old, married and has two children aged 13 and 16. She joined one of Hope’s groups named “Succès Plus” (a DRCongo microfinance program) in April 2009 and is the leader of that group which consists of 38 members. Thanks to Hope’s loans, the group members’ businesses have prospered.

Germaine has been active in her business since 1982. She runs a sewing workshop and sells sewing accessories to the east of Kinshasa. She is dedicated to her business which generates a profit of $200 per month. Her business is the only source of income which she has to support her family. Germaine has already received and successfully repaid four loans. She is planning with the coming loan to purchase sewing accessories of good quality that are needed by her clients in order to generate more profit. Her dream is to open a sewing center in her locality.

loans.use: To increase her stock of sewing accessories

loans.name: Wevina

texts.en: Wevina C., 51 years old, is a farmer and a sari-sari store owner. She sells a variety of goods and at the same time grows rice in Trento Agusan Del Sur. Wevina has two children, the eldest eight years old. Because a very small capitalization impedes her dreams of expanding her business, she is requesting a loan of Php 14,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy additional merchandise for the store as well as farm supplies.

loans.use: Additional merchandise to resell and farm supplies

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en: Nulu is a single mother of four children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Nulu owns a stall in Ndeeba market selling bananas. She doesn’t incur any transport costs because she buys from her place of work.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She has been doing this business for over 18 years. She pays monthly market dues. Nulu sells at retail and at wholesale. Nulu works seven days a week. Her business challenges include seasonality and the ever-increasing price of bananas.  Nulu has been with MCDT for seven and half years servicing her 20th loan. Her goals and aspirations are to educate her children up to university and to start going directly to farmers for her bananas. She joined MCDT because of being honest and transparent in loan appraisals. Nulu lives in a three-room house where she stays with eight people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family and market dues.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian G. is currently in the business of selling beans and maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and onions to sell. Lilian is 27 years old and is married to a teacher. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.
